siteInfo.heroSubtitle: Mapping the Galaxy's Most Precise Timekeepers
siteInfo.heroDescription: Our multi-phase program (PSRπ, MSPSRπ, MSPSRπ2) uses Very Long Baseline Interferometry to measure millisecond pulsar positions throughout the Galaxy. The VLBA achieves parallax and proper motion accuracies of ~40 microarcseconds and ~40 microarcseconds/year for pulsars as faint as 1 mJy. These precise measurements help us enhance gravitational wave detection, test Einstein's theories, and map dark matter distribution, effectively creating a cosmic GPS network that reveals the invisible structure of spacetime.

projectPhasesDescription: Spanning over a decade of research, our program has evolved through three phases

psrpi.title: PSRPI (2011-2013)
psrpi.subtitle: Original Pulsar Parallax Initiative
psrpi.description: The PSRPI program laid the groundwork for high-precision astrometry of pulsars using Very Long Baseline Interferometry. This initial phase targeted 60 pulsars and developed key observational techniques.
objectives: Improve understanding of Galactic electron distribution
Create foundation for millisecond pulsar astrometry
achievements: Published comprehensive catalogs of pulsar proper motions

mspsrpi.title: MSPSRPI (2015-2018)
mspsrpi.subtitle: Focused Millisecond Pulsar Astrometry Initiative
mspsrpi.description: Building on PSRπ, this phase exclusively targeted millisecond pulsars due to their exceptional rotational stability and importance for gravitational wave detection through pulsar timing arrays.
objectives: Measure precise distances to 18 millisecond pulsars with VLBA
Enhance tests of gravitational theories through binary pulsar measurements
Provide astrometric priors to improve pulsar timing array sensitivity
Refine Galactic electron density distribution models
achievements: Obtained significant parallax measurements for 15 out of 18 millisecond pulsars
Created 'sterne', a specialized Bayesian astrometry inference package
Measured the most significant model-independent distance for a double neutron star system (PSR J1518+4904)

mspsrpi2.title: MSPSRPI2 (2022-Present)
mspsrpi2.subtitle: Extended Millisecond Pulsar Astrometry Campaign
mspsrpi2.description: The second phase of MSPSRPI commenced in 2024 with VLBA project code BD247. This phase targets 44 pulsars, all of which are currently being observed by one or more pulsar timing arrays, representing a significant expansion of the millisecond pulsar sample studied with VLBI astrometry.
objectives: Determine precise astrometric parameters for pulsar timing array sources
Expand the sample of millisecond pulsars with model-independent distances
Support ongoing gravitational wave detection efforts through improved astrometry
Further refine our understanding of the Galactic millisecond pulsar population
achievements: Observational progress can be tracked below [MSPSRPI2 Progress Tracker]
Analysis pipeline established based on methodologies developed in MSPSRPI
Collaborative framework established with international pulsar timing arrays
